b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (18:43): To ensure that I have read this correctly: If I have a parser-inserted <script> that (synchronously) removes a subtree containing itself from the tree and, later in the same subtree have another script, that second script will not be run
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (18:44): Because the second script is not in a document at the time we prepare it

5ab883081f731227c31edbc84b0a6389 (18:46): Hey guys. How do you send correctly formatted mailing list stuff from a yahoo email? Apparently when I use yahoo mail the font is too large or wrong. What font and size do people use? I keep doing it wrong :\ Is there like a separate client people use to view and post to mailing lists?
1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb (18:47): Can you send plaintext email?
1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb (18:47): That's what most of us do.  Using HTML email is a failure.
1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb (18:48): For formatting in plaintext, most people use Markdown or some ad hoc variant.
5ab883081f731227c31edbc84b0a6389 (18:49): Cool I got it working. There was a "plain text" and "rich text" mode.

1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb (18:58): Okay, so this is an interesting proposal from Sylvain.  Plan for the "From-Origin" header to let sites opt into same-origin restrictions for any resource.  Then, have @font-face act as if "From-Origin:same" was sent by default (overrideable by actually sending From-Origin).
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (19:04): 1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb: That doesn't seem to address othermaciej/annevk's consistency objections

1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb (19:06): It partially does.  The default behavior of fonts is different, but they're all controllable with the same mechanism in this proposal, unlike the existing idea of using SOR+CORS for font, and From-Origin for other things.

88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (19:54): uses HTML escapes to avoid the issue
